text: Americans and and many people in other
countries love coffee and you know any
any time there's a behavior that is
engaged in on a repetitive and daily
basis we have a tendency to want to call
something like that an addiction
and it turns out really addiction is a
is a really specific form of brain
disorder that really has four major
components to that and that is that you
are experiencing negative consequences
because of your use and despite those
negative consequences you continue to
use or engage in that behavior so that's
a really key component to this the
second one is that the person becomes
significantly preoccupied with the use
of that substance or that behavior in a
way that that behavior becomes the
all-consuming focus of their life to the
detriment or their family their friends
their jobs all of their other interests
so when people talk about things like
coffee addiction those two pieces of it
tend to be missing what is common
between coffee addiction and other forms
of addiction is the physiological
dependence that forms on the active
ingredient that's a coffee which
everyone knows is caffeine so caffeine
is a stimulant so it's in the same class
of drugs as nicotine which is in
cigarettes it's also the same category
as cocaine amphetamine methamphetamine
the medications that are used for
attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
those are all stimulants they are all
chemicals that one can become
physiologically dependent on so people
become physiologically dependent on
their coffee there's sort of no question
about that and if they stop it they will
experience some type of kind of
withdrawal effect on that but it's not
the same really as calling it as an
addiction again because you don't have
these significant negative consequences
you don't have this focus on coffee to
the extent of work friendships family
